intro: Galium megalanthum, commonly known as the giant bedstraw, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the southwestern United States. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family, which includes many flowering plants known for their diverse morphological features. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and is often found in arid or semi-arid environments. Its stems are prostrate or ascending, and it produces small, white or pale yellow flowers in clusters. Galium megalanthum is characterized by its hairy foliage and is often used in xeriscaping due to its drought tolerance.
